docs.lead_paragraph: THE MARINES OF AUTUMN By James Brady Thomas Dunne Books/St. Martin's Press. 274 pages. $24.95. It's fair to say that the Korean War does not occupy a pivotal place in the collective American memory, certainly not compared with the sweep of World War II or the national preoccupation with the war in Vietnam. But it was a grim and unrelenting contest, twice almost lost, once almost won before it ended in a negotiated stalemate whose on-the-ground results endure today. Of course those who fought in Korea, like James Brady, author of ''The Marines of Autumn,'' do not share the national amnesia. Mr. Brady's novel about the war is almost brought down by the weight of stock war-novel devices. Even so, it transforms his bitter memory of the conflict into a gritty reconstruction of one of the war's most harrowing moments. That was the Chinese attack on American Marine and Army divisions that were proceeding foolishly past the earlier Korean line of demarcation at the 38th parallel all the way to the border with China. Again, it is probably safe to say that the site of the Chinese attack, which began around the Chosin Reservoir in the rugged, snowy Taibaik Mountains, is pretty much unknown to most Americans. Mr. Brady brings the battle there vividly to life, and death, in a novel that is more like a fictionalized documentary than a full-fledged work of the imagination.

headline.main: Marines in a Grim and Forgotten War

docs.lead_paragraph: To her English teacher at McClymonds High, one of the lowest-achieving schools in Oakland, Mara Chavez-Diaz was a beacon -- the food cart owners' daughter who aspired to lift the grade point average of the entire school. Mara is ''the kind of person,'' the teacher, Marsha Rhynes, said, ''who wakes up in the morning and says, 'Aha, I have an idea.' '' But Ms. Chavez-Diaz, on the verge of academic stardom, became pregnant, precipitating a downward spiral from which she is still rebounding.

headline.main: The Pomp of Graduation After Overcoming Difficult Circumstances

docs.abstract: Profiles of seniors who have overcome huge odds, including poverty, drug addiction of parents and other challenging family situations, to graduate from Oakland, Calif, high schools; such students intrigue sociologists, psychologists and educators because of the students' resilience; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The Personal Health column ''What Could Be Good About Morning Sickness? Plenty'' (June 6) appropriately reminded pregnant women of the importance of the B vitamin folic acid in preventing serious birth defects of the brain and spinal cord. But the vast majority of the 60 million women of childbearing age in this country still do not know that in order to be effective, the vitamin must be consumed every day beginning before conception and continuing into the first three months of pregnancy.
docs.abstract: March of Dimes president Dr Jennifer L Howse letter lauds June 6 Personal Health column for reminding pregnant women of importance of B vitamin folic acid in preventing birth defects of brain and spinal cord; notes few women know that vitamin should be taken before conception; drawing

docs.lead_paragraph: What's ''normal''? That's the question dozens of researchers and some physicians are now asking themselves about homocysteine, a substance in blood that may rival cholesterol as a major actor in the nation's leading killer, heart disease, and play an important role in other common health problems as well. Recent evidence has implicated elevated blood levels of homocysteine, an unhappy byproduct of normal metabolism, in conditions ranging from miscarriages and birth defects to strokes, Alzheimer's disease and other disorders that afflict older people, including osteoporosis and presbyopia, the eye changes that force the middle-aged to acquire reading glasses.

headline.main: Health Sleuths Assess Homocysteine as Culprit

docs.abstract: Normal levels of homocysteine, amino acid that is metabolic byproduct, are in doubt in face of recent studies showing blood levels still listed as normal by medical laboratories significantly raise risk of heart attack and other cardiovascular ailments; Dr William Castelli calls substance, associated with diet rich in animal protein, important new risk factor, interview; cites eating less meat and taking B vitamins as harmless and inexpensive way to lower homocysteine; diagram of how substance blocks arteries; tables of factors increasing homocysteine levels and of diseases linked to high levels (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Some of the most moving experiences in Phil Mickelson's life and career have taken place during the past 12 months. He engaged in a classic final-round duel last June with Payne Stewart, losing the United States Open by one stroke, after Stewart made a remarkable 18-foot putt on the last hole. Less than 24 hours later, Mickelson was in an Arizona hospital, watching his wife, Amy, give birth to their first child, Amanda Brynn.

headline.main: GOLF: A Birth, a Death And a Burning Desire; Mickelson Wants to Win the U.S. Open, Badly

docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's ruling today that a patient cannot use the federal Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 to sue a health maintenance organization for giving doctors a financial incentive to cut treatment costs. Justice David H. Souter wrote the opinion for a unanimous court. The question in this case is whether treatment decisions made by a health maintenance organization, acting through its physician employees, are fiduciary acts within the meaning of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. . . . We hold that they are not.

headline.main: Excerpts From Court's Ruling on Suing H.M.O.'s

docs.lead_paragraph: Ask Gov. George W. Bush of Texas about the intellectual origins of his campaign's mantra and he says, ''Compassionate conservatism is first and foremost springing from the heart.'' Yet well before Mr. Bush began building his presidential campaign around the words ''compassionate conservative'' -- reshaping the image of his party to follow suit -- a cadre of thinkers on the right had been trying for years to fashion a form of conservatism that rejected the welfare state but did not turn its back on the poor. And with his campaign strategist Karl Rove acting as his guide, Mr. Bush began reading their books and meeting them, even before his first race for governor.

headline.main: Bush Draws Campaign Theme From More Than 'the Heart'

docs.lead_paragraph: In the next decade, a baby's first checkup won't be in the pediatrician's office. It will be in the petri dish while she's an eight-cell embryo no bigger than a dust speck. We are a long way from designing children with button noses, blond hair and 150 I.Q.'s. But by 2010, geneticists say they'll be able to predict babies' propensities for many of the diseases we dread most: breast, colon and prostate cancer, heart disease, diabetes. The key will be a DNA chip. With one amplified droplet of DNA, a thumbnail-size chip will be able to vet embryos for hundreds of genetic diseases.

headline.main: Tech 2010: #20 No Surprises; The Genetic Report Card That Will Tell You If Your Embryo Will Get Prostate Cancer

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The problems caused by the transition to managed care are enormous, but ''New H.M.O. Fight: Medical Discipline'' (May 28) missed an important aspect of the debate. The common perception among health care consumers (formerly known as patients) is that coverage by a health maintenance organization provides all the care options needed to ensure health. In fact, it means coverage for what an employer has chosen to pay. The same insurer may deny coverage under one policy and approve it under another.
docs.abstract: Dr Terence M O'Connor, letter, responds to May 28 article on managed care; points out that HMOs merely enforce coverage decisions that are in fact made by employers and benefits managers (M)
